this is a fab topic to bring up :) im taking a lil break from my essay researching ahah so ill share my experience briefly (lol not really) !!! I'm an ABK so born and raised in Australia and I am really lucky in the sense that I have retained my language skills in a way that is more 'advanced'. I can communicate fluently with my family and am comfortable talking, albeit not 100% like a native, with other elders about economic issues and political things as well. I was raised with grandparents in the house who immigrated here in the 80s and a mum who spoke to us both in korean and english (she did high school and university here). I went to korean school for about 4-5 years when I was in primary school and have gone to korea to see family once every 3/4 years. Despite having a pretty good grasp of the language I have to say, I only really identify myself as korean in terms of my ethnicity and partial cultural background. I had a really interesting experience recently where I attended a korean church in the uk (i was meant to be there for the duration of this year on exchange) and I found it a really mixed time making friends with the other korean students there. As most of them were students from korea doing their post grad/undergrad studies in the uk, I found I couldn't really relate to them with a lot of things. Humour, general interests, involvement within the university, types of friends etc. (Side note, mind you this is coming from someone who has attended korean church in australia their entire life). I think from the experience overall, I have realised more and more that gyopyoss are their own category. I am as Aussie as anyone else in my schooling and life experiences but obviously I have come from a background that is so different to a standard 'caucasian family'. I can communicate well, read, write okay and listen but my mannerisms, knowledge of slang, more complicated phrases expressed in dramas/reality tv will never be to the standard of a native (obviously). I tend to be more into western shows, music and have a very diverse group of mates so maybe in an alternative version of myself where I was more invested in korean culture I could weave my way into better suiting with native koreans. But I'm pretty happy with my cultural identity the way it is atm :)

(I'm tired and will probably ramble on and talk in circles so I apologize in advance lol). I was born in Seoul but was adopted when I was 3 months old so I grew up white. My parents were always encouraging me to learn about Korea when I was younger but I really pushed it away, as is very common among the adoptee population. For a lot of us adoptees, we didn't grow up with any exposure to other Koreans (or any Asians or other minorities for that matter), and with even our families being non-Korean, it really puts a strain on the whole identity crisis, for a lack of better term; and I've found most adoptees try to assimilate into white American culture as much as possible. I really hated being Asian growing up, and it wasn't until my senior year of high school that I peaked interest. I taught myself how to read hangul and some basic phrases, but that was about it. In 2015-2016 I moved to Korea and spent some time doing language programs at a university, and then I did that again in 2018-2019. My language skills are definitely not what I consider fluent. But because I started taking language classes when I was 23 after never hearing any Korean in my life, I'm both proud of how much I've learned and also mad I'm not better since I lived there for 2 years and plan on moving back again this year lol. I'm still fairly comfortable with my current level (somewhere between high intermediate and low advanced), although not necessarily confident or content with my current level. I have no problem getting around, having conversations, etc., to the point that my most recent ex only spoke Korean, so it's no longer a HUGE issue, but I still am always concerned that my Korean isn't good enough, and that I'm not culturally Korean enough. Frankly, I've tried really hard to assimilate into Korean culture, with language-learning being a key factor, but I think a lot of this goes back to adoption, as I personally feel as an adoptee needing to prove myself, since I didn't even grow up in a Korean household.

Moving to a new part of Queens from middle school was a little hard because we were raised in a predominantly Asian population. This move to a non-Asian community, made me become a translator for my parents because important school documents were never translated in Korean (whereas previously that wasn't an issue). It was a little hard trying to fit in, but I found myself accepting my differences in high school as I hung out with friends from multi ethnic backgrounds. Sometimes, I still feel bothered to have to translate for my parents, but I'm recognizing what a privilege it is to be bilingual. Languages are beautiful and being able to communicate is a blessing in itself! When I travel to Korea, it is special being able to speak to my relatives, knowing what/how to order, and overall having an easy way of getting around! Kudos to my parents for being immigrants. I personally cannot imagine packing up and leaving to another country as they have.. makes me grateful and shifts my perspective.

1. Am I comfortable with my Korean language skills right now? Id say Im comfortable with where I am, knowing that Im always keen to broaden my vocabulary and get better at honourifics. 2. Do I feel like I either belong or do not belong to a Korean identity because of my language skills right now? This is a difficult question for me. Having a dual cultural identity, with a Korean mum, has always made it harder for me to feel like I belong. At Korean church I was the only mixed Korean kid, and even being a fluent 4/5 year old left me on the outskirts (socially). Language never felt like it made me belong because I dont look ethnically Korean; but language was definitely a useful tool/mechanism that aided me in feeling more connected to my Korean side. This is something I am extremely grateful for, because I think I wouldve felt even more othered if I hadnt been able to speak it fluently.  3. How do I feel when speaking to others in Korea? It feels really fucking weird. Again, because I dont ethnically look Korean, people are almost always shocked that Im able to converse with them, or understand what theyre saying. Theres this look of absolute disbelief when you order food or tickets or say something in Korean, I presume because of the assumptions theyve made about my physical features immediately others me as an outsider. In those moments I feel a mixed sense of pride, followed by validation that my Korean is good, then I feel quite sad that this would never happen to ethnically looking Koreans who grew up outside of Korea. Instead of being praised for speaking the best Korean they can, theyre held to a higher language standard because they just look like they should be fluent. Whereas I seem to never face criticism, but only praise for speaking my mothers tongue. Speaking to family or family friends in Korea is also weird. SO many times people will talk to me through my mum - ask her questions about me, like what am I studying, expecting me to not understand. Its really weird and it makes me feel the need to prove myself through fluency of Korean to them. Like I have to justify that I do belong because I can speak the language. This happens to close family friends too, ones I known since I was born. They ask me questions in English, and I respond, confused, in Korean, and weirdly they just continue to speak to me in English, even though they clearly prefer Korean. I think my experiences are extremely different to those ethnically Korean passing diasporic kids. Being mixed race, fluent in Korean person has definitely had its pros and cons. Even though I constantly feel othered, I feel that I gain acceptance in the community through my language use. I cant imagine how hard it must be for other mixed kids, who already feel like outsiders to both groups (Asian people see us as white and white people see us as Asian), who dont speak both languages of their cultures.

1.5er here. Born in Korea, immigrated in 1979, 2 months before turning 5, 3 months before kindergarten. My mom taught me to read and write before leaving Korea, and I'd like to think I remembered everything my mom taught me, so my Korean level is perfectly preserved at the 5-year-old level. I grew up in Northern California, and my church had Korean school which was useless to me because I already knew how to read and write at a level higher than what they offered in the 80s, albeit still at the 5-year-old level. My grandmother came from Korea to live with us when I was in 7th grade, by which time I was aware that my Korean was not that good, but thankfully her being in the house kept my Korean in better shape than it otherwise would've been. I certainly felt like I was more Korean than American, partly because my Korean was still better than that of my peers, but also because of the bullies in the 80s who never let me feel American. In college I signed up for a Korean language class, and for the placement interview I was warned by students older than me that I need to fake how bad my Korean was, because you don't want to get placed into an impossibly higher class than you can handle. Because it was for the spring semester, the only class that was available was 1-2, 2-2, or 3-2. I knew 2-2 would be too hard, so I tried to take my way into the 1-2 class. I did well there and learned a ton, but was recommended to take 3-1 next semester. When I had my babies in the mid-2000s, I had made up in my mind that they would speak Korean, so I spoke ONLY Korean to them, knowing that eventually I'd have to switch to English when they're older and their Korean grammar needs become higher than what I can offer them. That shift happened around when they turned 5. Funny thing was, when they were 2 and 4, we went to Korea to visit my in-laws, and all the relatives commented that their Korean was better than mine. Yup, I taught them everything they knew. My husband specifically refused to speak Korean to the kids, much to my disappointment. Because of my limited Korean, I never feel comfortable visiting Korea. My bil and his family lived in the US ever since the 20th century, but recently they moved with their 3 kids to Korea for work. I think I'd be pretty frustrated if I was in his wife's position. Growing up I felt more Korean than American, but when I visited Korea, I felt too American. Funny thing is, when I lived in the Midwest for 7 years, I found out that my true identity is Korean-American Californian. My experience is closer to those growing up in California than anywhere else.
